title: How to Be a Happy Person Without Religion

steps.title: Make an effort to be happy.
steps.content: Make an effort to be happy . A great deal of what it takes to be happy has nothing to do with being religious or atheist, but instead depends on your general attitude towards the world. To make an effort, be honest with yourself and tell yourself you are going to try your best to become happier.

steps.title: Challenge self-fulfilling prophecies.
steps.content: Challenge self-fulfilling prophecies. Self-fulfilling prophecies are ideas that become true because you believe them. [2] X Research source If you believe that atheists are generally unhappy, and if you are an atheist, you may act in ways that reinforce your belief, thereby making you less happy. To avoid self-fulfilling prophecies, try to change your belief that atheists are generally unhappy. You ask yourself some questions such as: "is it logical that someone needs to believe in a particular religion to be happy?" "when am I most happy? Is it when I'm thinking about religion or is it when I'm doing fun things, hanging out with friends, thinking deeply, or taking in nature?"

steps.title: Embrace your atheism.
steps.content: Embrace your atheism. In doing so, recognize the reasons you have chosen to be an Atheist . Mental reaffirmation will build confidence in yourself, your beliefs, or lack thereof, and your choices. Changing who you are for others is a surefire way to become less happy and have less self-worth - so if you truly don't believe there is any god or supernatural being overseeing the universe, stick with it despite any persecution that may come your way. [3] X Trustworthy Source Simply Psychology Popular site for evidence-based psychology information Go to source

steps.title: Don't believe the stereotypes.
steps.content: Don't believe the stereotypes. There are stereotypes out there that atheists are bad people, that they have no moral compass, and that they are unhappy. To counteract these stereotypes, think about some happy atheists that you know. If you don't know any, think about some famous atheists who seem pretty happy, such as Richard Dawkins or Sam Harris. To see a happy atheist, watch this funny video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gW7607YiBso

steps.title: Try to recognize the cultural value of religion.
steps.content: Try to recognize the cultural value of religion. This will help you understand and get along with people of any religion. While organized religion as an institution has many clear flaws, there are also good aspects, so it is important to respect people's choices regarding religious beliefs.. It may be as simple as the music associated with the religion, or perhaps you may find portions of a religions' moral code admirable. People may find that religion offers them comfort, community, and morals. This can be meaningful for people who choose to be religious.

steps.title: Join a like-minded community.
steps.content: Join a like-minded community. Social connection is important for happiness and stress reduction. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Depending on where you are from, being an atheist can mean losing ones friends or even family. It is important to replace lost social connections with new ones. Join a like-minded community who you can socialize with from time to time. This could be a humanist group, an atheist group, or some other group that is entirely associated with beliefs and values.

steps.title: Be generous
steps.content: Be generous . Studies show that when you give to others, your happiness increases. [5] X Trustworthy Source Greater Good Magazine Journal published by UC Berkeley's Greater Good Science Center, which uses scientific research to promote happier living Go to source And, you don't need to believe in any gods to decide to be good and generous. You can choose to either give your time or your money; what matters most is that you are providing a benefit to someone else that makes them happy. In doing so, you will be happier, too.

steps.title: Smile.
steps.content: Smile. Studies show that there is a bi-directional relationship between the facial muscles and feelings of emotion. In other words, if you make yourself smile, you might just feel a little happier, regardless of your religious beliefs or lack thereof. [6] X Research source Try setting a reminder on your phone to remind yourself to smile more often. For example, you could set a reminder for every two or three hours throughout the day to remind yourself to smile more. You could have it say something simple like, "Are you smiling right now?"

steps.title: When dealing with religious people, avoid argument and conflict.
steps.content: When dealing with religious people, avoid argument and conflict. People are very unlikely to change their minds about their beliefs. [7] X Research source Unless the conversation is very important to you, it may be best to let it go. It's not because it's about religion per se, but people's beliefs about most things that evoke emotions (e.g., their political beliefs) are difficult to change.

steps.title: Exercise.
steps.content: Exercise. Get outside and go for a run or go to the gym and do some resistance training. Try to get moderate exercise for 30 minutes at least three times a week. Studies show that working out your body can improve your mood. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source To get a more intense workout, try listening to some upbeat music and keeping up with the rhythm.

steps.title: Cultivate your relationships.
steps.content: Cultivate your relationships. Spend time on your friends and loved ones. Surrounding yourself with a supportive community will help you feel energized and happy.
